The fact that TMPD oxidase activity is not impaired by the mutations demonstrates that the active site for the reduction of O2 (i.e. heme b595/heme d binuclear center) is fully functional in these mutants. The heme analysis and the UV-visible reduced minus oxidized difference spectra of each of the purified mutant oxidases indicate no substantial differences compared with the wild type enzyme (Table I and Fig. 2). The R391A mutant was selected as representative of the set of mutants and subjected to more detailed examination. The EPR spectrum of the fully oxidized R391A mutant oxidase was found to be essentially identical to the spectrum of the wild type oxidase (not shown). This similarity includes the unusual highly asymmetric low spin spectral feature near g = 3.5 arising from the low spin heme b558 component of the oxidase (29Spinner F. Cheesman M.R. Thomson A.J. Kaysser T. Gennis R.B. Peng Q. Peterson J. Biochem. J. 1995; 308: 641-644Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). These studies show that the mutations do not perturb the assembly of the enzyme or result in a gross conformational change of the enzyme and do not perturb the local structure around any of the three heme prosthetic groups to the extent that the EPR or UV-visible spectra are altered. CO Binding to Heme d—Another useful probe of perturbations caused by the Arg391 mutants is the binding of CO to the oxidase. CO binds to the ferrous heme d component of the enzyme. Spectroscopic changes to the hemes were monitored upon titrating CO into a solution of the dithionite-reduced R391A and wild type oxidases. The changes induced by CO binding are identical for the two enzymes (not shown). In addition, CO was photodissociated from the enzyme, and the recombination kinetics was examined. In each case, the recombination kinetics (not shown) are biphasic, with rates of 266 s–1 (k1) and 15.5 s–1 (k2) for the wild type cytochrome bd and 133 s–1 (k1) and 6 s–1 (k2) for the R391A mutant. It is concluded that there is no substantial perturbation by the R391A mutant, confirming that the active site for O2 binding (heme b595/heme d binuclear center) is essentially unchanged by the mutation. The spectra of both mutants are very similar to that of the wild type enzyme, consistent with the conclusion that the mutations do not result in any large conformational changes. In the haloarchaea Haloferax volcanii, ribosomes are found in the cytoplasm and membrane-bound at similar levels. Transformation of H. volcanii to express chimeras of the translocon components SecY and SecE fused to a cellulose-binding domain substantially decreased ribosomal membrane binding, relative to non-transformed cells, likely due to steric hindrance by the cellulose-binding domain. Treatment of cells with the polypeptide synthesis terminator puromycin, with or without low salt washes previously shown to prevent in vitro ribosomal membrane binding in halophilic archaea, did not lead to release of translocon-bound ribosomes, indicating that ribosome release is not directly related to the translation status of a given ribosome. Release was, however, achieved during cell starvation or stationary growth, pointing at a regulated manner of ribosomal release in H. volcanii. Decreased ribosomal binding selectively affected membrane protein levels, suggesting that membrane insertion occurs co-translationally in Archaea. In the presence of chimera-incorporating sterically hindered translocons, the reduced ability of ribosomes to bind in the transformed cells modulated protein synthesis rates over time, suggesting that these cells manage to compensate for the reduction in ribosome binding. Possible strategies for this compensation, such as a shift to a post-translational mode of membrane protein insertion or maintained ribosomal membrane-binding, are discussed.

The last four years have seen many constructive activities designed to enhance the postdoc experience. The greatest remaining concern is the quality of mentoring by advisers. Many principal investigators view postdocs not as apprentices but as skilled, bargain-rate assistants, who become increasingly valuable with time. In this Policy Forum,
 Maxine Singer
 notes that when the independence of junior researchers is postponed, science suffers. Other strategies and incentives are discussed that can promote continued constructive change in the postdoctoral system.

The integrin αvβ3 has been shown to exist in low and high affinity conformations. Activation to the high affinity state is thought to depend on the “switchblade-like” opening, from a low affinity bent conformation with a closed headpiece to an extended form of the integrin with an open headpiece. Activation has been shown to depend on separation of the cytoplasmic domains. How cytoplasmic domain separation is related to separation of the transmembrane domains is unknown, and the distance of separation of the transmembrane domains required for activation has not been defined. A constrained secreted form of αvβ3 was engineered that introduced a 50-Å separation of the integrin C-terminal tails of the extracellular domains of the αv and β3 subunits. Receptor binding and recognition by ligand-induced binding state (LIBS) monoclonal antibodies demonstrated that the mutant receptor was locked into a low affinity state that was likely in a partially extended conformation but with a closed headpiece. In the presence of RGD peptide, the constrained receptor was able to fully extend, as determined by full exposure of LIBS epitopes. In the presence of the appropriate LIBS antibody, high affinity ligand binding of the constrained receptor was achieved. The results support the existence of transient intermediate activation states of secreted αvβ3. Furthermore, these results with the secreted αvβ3 receptor support a model for the full-length membrane-bound form of αvβ3, whereby a 50-Å lateral separation of the integrin αv and β3 transmembrane domains would be sufficient to enforce the switchblade-like opening to the extended conformation but insufficient for full receptor activation. Activation to the high affinity state is thought to depend on the “switchblade-like” opening, from a low affinity bent conformation with a closed headpiece to an extended form of the integrin with an open headpiece. Activation has been shown to depend on separation of the cytoplasmic domains. How cytoplasmic domain separation is related to separation of the transmembrane domains is unknown, and the distance of separation of the transmembrane domains required for activation has not been defined. Receptor binding and recognition by ligand-induced binding state (LIBS) monoclonal antibodies demonstrated that the mutant receptor was locked into a low affinity state that was likely in a partially extended conformation but with a closed headpiece. Integrins are heterodimeric type I transmembrane proteins consisting of a single α and β subunit that mediates their effects on development, homeostasis, vessel growth, inflammation, hemostasis, and neoplasia through dynamic linkages between the extracellular matrix and cytoskeleton (1Humphries M.J. McEwan P.A. Barton S.J. Buckley P.A. Bella J. Mould A.P. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2003; 28: 313-320Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). Presumably, inside-out signaling proceeds by separation of the α and β legs, which leads to structural rearrangements in the integrin headpiece (i.e. priming). Conversely, ligand binding would lead to structural rearrangements of the headpiece that would then lead to conformational alteration of the α and β legs (i.e. activation). However, the role of separation of the α and β legs and the sequence of conformational events leading to integrin receptor priming and activation remain to be elucidated.In this report, we have used crystallographic data of integrin αvβ3 and placental alkaline phosphatase to design an integrin fusion protein that directly tests the role of a defined spatial separation (50-Å) of the integrin α and β legs in mediating long range global changes in conformation of the αvβ3 integrin. We have shown that this 50-Å separation is sufficient to expose β3 tail domain activation epitopes but insufficient to induce high affinity ligand binding. We demonstrated that full activation of the secreted receptor requires further conformational changes, most likely localized in the integrin headpiece. These data with a secreted form of αvβ3 provide a model of receptor activation for membrane-bound αvβ3, whereby separation of the α and β tail domains exposes the headpiece-tailpiece interface leading to an extended conformer priming the receptor for ligand engagement.MATERIALS AND METHODSConstructs, Antibodies, and Reagents–The αv extracellular domain alkaline phosphatase (αv-AP) 1The abbreviations used are: AP, alkaline phosphatase; LIBS, ligand-induced binding state; tr, truncated; TBS, Tris-buffered saline; M-, monomeric; D-, dimeric. fusion was constructed from αv-pCDM8 (14Weinacker A. Cell Biol. 2002; 157: 493-507Crossref PubMed Scopus (584) Google Scholar).Receptor Binding Assays–Serum-free supernatants in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (MediaTech, Herndon, VA) were harvested after 48 h, sterile filtered, and either passed over a desalting column (PD-10, Amersham Biosciences) or dialyzed using 100,000 molecular weight cut-off tubing (Spectrum, Los Angeles, CA) into assay buffer (Tris 10 mm, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl (TBS)) and then concentrated using a 50,000 molecular weight cut-off concentrator (Millipore). Alkaline phosphatase activity was quantified by luminometry using Phosphalight™ (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA). Receptor samples were normalized by diluting as appropriate in TBS. Equal amounts and concentrations of receptors were added in the presence of 0.5 mm Ca2+ and 0.5 mm Mg2+ (TBS-CaMg) with or without LIBS-1, -2, or -6 (10 μg/μl), 1.0 mm Mn2+ (TBS-Mn), or GRGDNP (50 μg/ml; BIOMOL, Plymouth Meeting, PA) to individual wells of 96-well plates precoated with 10 μg/μl vitronectin, fibronectin, collagen I, fibrinogen (Calbiochem, La Jolla, CA), LIBS-1, -2, or -6, mouse anti-αv (8B8), or mouse anti-alkaline phosphatase. Nonspecific binding sites were blocked with bovine serum albumin (10 mg/ml) (A3803, Sigma). After incubation for 3 h at 23 °C, individual wells of the plates were washed extensively with TBS-CaMg or TBS-Mn, depending on the assay, and then treated with p-nitrophenyl phosphate (Sigma). Bound receptor was determined by absorbance (A405) of the test sample minus absorbance (A405) of a duplicate well coated only with bovine serum albumin (10 mg/ml). All assays were performed at least in triplicate.Statistical Analysis–Analysis of variance (for parametric data) or the Kruskal-Wallis test (for non-parametric data) was used for more than 2 data sets. Tukey's or Dunn's test was used for parametric or non-parametric data, respectively, to determine where the differences lay. Significance was defined as p < 0.05. Data are shown as means ± 1 S.E., unless otherwise noted. The statistical software used was Prism v3.0 (GraphPad Software Inc., San Diego, CA).RESULTSαvβ3 Integrin-Alkaline Phosphatase Fusion Proteins Are Secreted and Form a C-terminally Constrained Heterodimer and a C-terminally Non-constrained Dimer of Heterodimers–To examine the effect of transmembrane separation on integrin function, we created soluble secreted forms of αvβ3 with physically constrained and non-constrained C termini. We fused the C termini of the integrin αv (αv-AP) and β3 (β3-AP) subunits to the N terminus of the mature secreted form of human placental alkaline phosphatase to create a C-terminally constrained integrin (Fig. 1A). Analysis of the crystal structure of human placental alkaline phosphatase (Protein Data Bank code 1EW2) reveals a homodimeric molecule where the N termini are separated 50 Å by an interfacial wedge-shaped crown domain composed of 60 residues from each monomer (20Le Du M.H. Stigbrand T. Taussig M.J. Menez A. Stura E.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 9158-9165Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). The extreme N termini embrace the opposite monomer and are thus likely involved in dimerization and are also likely involved in enzymatic activity, because they are in direct contact with residues involved in allostery (20Le Du M.H. Stigbrand T. Taussig M.J. Menez A. Stura E.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 9158-9165Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). Therefore, in the αvβ3-alkaline phosphatase fusion protein, the N termini of placental alkaline phosphatase would be expected to rigidly constrain the C termini of the integrin subunits in a fixed 50-Å separation. Furthermore, the wedge-shaped crown domain of placental alkaline phosphatase would intercalate between the αv and β3 subunit legs, further encouraging the separation of the α and β legs (Fig. 1C). Co-transfection of the β3 subunit-placental alkaline phosphatase fusion construct with the truncated αv construct without a placental alkaline phosphatase fusion (αv-tr) was predicted to result in a dimer of heterodimers of αvβ3 (D-αvβ3) integrins (Fig. 1, B and C). In contrast, co-transfection of the αv (αv-AP) and β3 (β3-AP) constructs with placental alkaline phosphatase fused to both C termini was predicted to result in a simple heterodimer of the αvβ3 (hereafter referred to as “monomeric” or M-αvβ3) integrin (Fig. 1, B and C). Indeed, no evidence of αv or β3 subunit homodimer formation was found, because only 293 cells transiently co-transfected with αv-AP and β3-AP or αv-tr and β3-AP led to significant increases in secreted alkaline phosphatase activity, and 293 cells transfected with the αv-AP or β3-AP constructs alone failed to produce any detectable alkaline phosphatase activity in the cell supernatant (data not shown). Metabolic labeling and immunoprecipitation of supernatant from 293 cells stably co-transfected with αv-tr and β3-AP or αv-AP and β3-AP constructs revealed two bands co-migrating at ∼140 and ∼150 kDa or migrating at 200 and 150 kDa, corresponding to the predicted migrations of αv-tr and β3-AP or αv-AP and β3-AP subunits, respectively (Fig. 1D). Heterodimer formation was confirmed because the same two bands could be immunoprecipitated by anti-αv, anti-β3, or anti-alkaline phosphatase antibodies (Fig. 1D). The identity of the bands was confirmed by Western blotting using anti-alkaline phosphatase antibodies, which revealed a single band migrating at 150 kDa and two bands migrating at 150 and 200 kDa from supernatants from 293 cells transfected with αv-tr and β3-AP or αv-AP and β3-AP, respectively (Fig. 1D). D- and M-αvβ3 were assessed by analytical gel filtration to determine the extent of receptor aggregation and to determine whether the position of the elution peaks was consistent with the proposed assembly of D- and M-αvβ3. Both receptors eluted in single major peaks, with M-αvβ3 eluting in a sharp peak from 11 to 12.5 ml and d-αvβ3 eluting in a broader peak from 8.5 to 11.5 ml (Fig. 1E). The peak elution fractions corresponded to molecular masses of 1488 and 663 kDa for D- and M-αvβ3, respectively, when compared with the molecular mass markers of globular protein standards (Fig. 1E, inset). The discrepancies in molecular mass as estimated by gel filtration from molecular mass as estimated by SDS-PAGE (550 kDa for D-αvβ3 and 340 kDa for M-αvβ3) are consistent with a dramatic increase in axial asymmetry as would be expected both for a fusion protein and also for secreted αvβ3 in an extended conformation (5Takagi J. Petre B.M. Walz T. Springer T.A. Cell. 2002; 110: 599-611Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (914) Google Scholar). There was no evidence of massive aggregate formation because no significant amount of either receptor could be found in the void volume. However, a minor peak at 10 ml was found with M-αvβ3, which may correspond to a small amount of multimeric M-αvβ3 (Fig. 1E). This miniscule amount of multimeric M-αvβ3 was unlikely to confound functional studies, because the vitronectin binding activity of M-αvβ3 closely corresponded to the position of the major elution peak, and minimal vitronectin binding activity was detected in the 10-ml fraction (Fig. 1F). The presence of the β3-AP subunit in the peak elution fractions of D-αvβ3 and of both the αv-AP and β3-AP subunits in peak elution fractions of M-αvβ3 was confirmed by Western blotting (Fig. 1F, inset). For the integrin-alkaline phosphatase fusions, it appears that the integrin α and β subunit association determines pairing rather than alkaline phosphatase monomer association. Therefore, the dimeric and monomeric integrin-alkaline phosphatase fusion proteins are expressed and secreted and pair to form proper integrin heterodimers, which are correctly folded with respect to antibody epitopes and functional activity.Monomeric αvβ3 Integrin-Alkaline Phosphatase Fusion Protein Is in a Low Affinity State and Is Fully Active in the Presence of Mn2+–The effect of a 50-Å separation of the extracellular domain C termini of αvβ3 on receptor function was tested in solid phase ligand binding assays. Constrained monomeric αvβ3 was inactive in the presence of Ca2+ and Mg2+, because it did not bind to its physiological ligands, vitronectin (VN), fibronectin (FN), and fibrinogen (Fb) (Fig. 2, A-C). However, monomeric αvβ3 (M-αvβ3) bound as well as dimeric αvβ3 (D-αvβ3) to VN, FN, and Fb in the presence of Mn2+ (Fig. 2, A-C). In the presence of Mn2+, both monomeric and dimeric αvβ3 bound well to VN and less well to FN and Fb, consistent with known αvβ3 ligand binding preferences (21Mehta R.J. Diefenbach B. Brown A. Cullen E. Jonczyk A. Gussow D. Luckenbach G.A. Goodman S.L. Biochem. J. 1998; 330: 861-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) (Fig. 2, A-C). This binding was specific, because no binding to an irrelevant ligand (Col I) was seen (Fig. 2D). Furthermore, no binding of control receptors, dimeric αvβ8 (D-αvβ8) and monomeric αvβ8 (M-αvβ8), was seen to VN, FN, Fb, or Col I (Fig. 2), consistent with known solid phase binding preferences of αvβ8 (15Mu D. Cambier S. Fjellbirkeland L. Baron J.L. Munger J.S. Kawakatsu H. Sheppard D. Broaddus V.C. Nishimura S.L. J. Cell Biol. 2002; 157: 493-507Crossref PubMed Scopus (584) Google Scholar). The dimeric form of αvβ3 was likely in a fully active state, because Mn2+ did not increase binding to VN, FN, or Fb (Fig. 2, A-C). Thus, Mn2+ induced a fully active state of monomeric spatially constrained αvβ3, because it bound to its ligands as well as the dimeric form of αvβ3 (Fig. 2, A-C). Therefore, a 50-Å separation of the C termini of the integrin αv and β3 extracellular domains does not constrain the receptor in a default-active conformation, nor does it constrain the receptor in a low affinity state, because Mn2+ can fully activate it.Fig. 2Monomeric αvβ3 integrin-alkaline phosphatase fusion protein is in a low affinity state and is fully active in the presence of Mn2+. Dimeric αvβ3 binding to VN was not affected by the addition of LIBS-1, -2, or -6 (Fig. 3F).DISCUSSIONIn this study, we have created novel spatially constrained secreted integrin αvβ3 heterodimers and have provided evidence that a 50-Å separation of the C-terminal tails of the α and β extracellular domains is sufficient to cause the “bent” inactive conformation of αvβ3 to “extend” to an intermediate activation state.The extracellular domains of αv and β3, when fused to the N termini of placental alkaline phosphatase (a homodimeric, stable, easily quantifiable, and sensitive reporter)

In 1954, the first device demonstrating microwave amplification by stimulated emission of radiation was demonstrated. Fifty years on, some masers are widely used as amplifiers and high-stability oscillators. Other, more novel maser designs are enabling fundamental studies of quantum mechanics and are providing sensitive tests for quantum gravity theories. In his Perspective,
 Walsworth
 reviews these recent developments. In a related Perspective,
 Claussen
 reviews the discovery and study of naturally occurring masers in astronomical objects such as star-forming regions.

Decoy receptor 3 (DcR3)/TR6/M68 is a soluble receptor that binds to the Fas ligand LIGHT and TL1A. Elevated levels of DcR3 expression have been found in many tumors. We report an unexpected effect of DcR3 by sensitizing Jurkat and U937 cells to apoptosis induced by tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL). Cell death triggered by anti-Fas and tumor necrosis factor was unaffected by DcR3. DcR3 by itself did not stimulate apoptosis. The ability to augment TRAIL-initiated cell death was not observed with soluble lymphotoxin β receptor or soluble death receptor 3, indicating that binding to LIGHT or TL1A alone is insufficient to trigger TRAIL sensitivity. Incubation with DcR3 did not increase the surface expression of TRAIL receptor, and the level of Fas-associated death domain protein and cellular FLICE-like inhibitory protein was not altered. Instead, in the presence of DcR3, TRAIL engagement resulted in an increased activation of caspase-8, an elevated cleavage of Bid, and enhanced release of Smac and cytochrome c from mitochondria to cytosol compared with TRAIL alone. This led to increased activation of caspase-9 and caspase-3. The unusual ability of DcR3 to promote TRAIL-triggered death may be used to potentiate TRAIL efficacy during treatment tumors overexpressing DcR3.
